free_text.Contenu: Approximate content :[br/][br/]- Human factors (physiology, anatomy, haptic sensation)   [br/]- Sensing in HRI (analogy between human and robot sensing)   [br/]- Data acquisition & real-time control Actuation in HRI   [br/]- Kinematics, transmissions, sensor collocation   [br/]- Basic modeling, electromechanical analogy , bond graphs  [br/]- Basic control   [br/]- Advanced modeling (friction identification and modeling)   [br/]- Advanced control (haptic rendering of rigid contact)   [br/]- Safety analysis and methods to minimize risks of injuries   [br/]- Performance metrics : step resp., bandwidth, friction, saturation, transparency, max acceleration, max velocity, user evaluation   [br/]- Student presentations
free_text.Objectifs d'apprentissage: Learning outcomes - domain skills :[br/][br/]Basic knowledge on haptic devices, force feedback, mechanical man-machine interfaces :[br/][br/]- Students can design and evaluate such systems  [br/]- Potential applications : Robot control (telemanipulators), interface with VR, robot assistive devices, rehabilitation devices[br/]- Know and identify critical physiological factors of the human somatosensory and motor system[br/]- Evaluate and define the characteristics and specifications of the mechatronic system using the bond-graph formalism [br/]- Derive and utilize dynamic models for design  [br/]- Select HW components and control strategy  [br/]- Characterize and optimize the system w.r.t. psychophysical and engineering criteria  [br/][br/]This lecture includes mandatory hands-on experiments and mini projects with a hardware device (the "haptic paddle")
